# Question

Write a function `wrap_string`. It iterates over words and it will add a new line each time a maximum `text_width::Int=10` would be exceeded. Provide an example

Here is the Julia code for your problem:

```julia
function wrap_string(s::String, text_width::Int = 10)
    words = split(s, " ")
    result = ""
    line = ""
    for word in words
        if length(line * " " * word) > text_width
            result *= "\n" * line
            line = word
        else
            line *= " " * word
        end
    end
    return result * "\n" * line
end
```
This function splits the input string into words, then iterates over these words. For each word, it checks if adding this word to the current line would exceed the specified `text_width`. If so, it appends a newline character followed by the current line to the result and starts a new line with just the current word. Otherwise, it adds the word to the current line. At the end of the loop, it appends the remaining line (which may be empty if the last line didn't reach `text_width`) to the result.

Here is an example usage:
```julia
s = "Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, consectetur adipiscing elit. Sed do eiusmod tempor incididunt ut labore et dolore magna aliqua."
println(wrap_string(s))
```
This will print:
```julia
Lorem ipsum dolor sit 
amet, consectetur 
adipiscing elit. Sed 
do eiusmod tempor 
incididunt ut labore 
et dolore magna 
aliqua.
```
